data.title: The Daily News
data.meta_description: The Daily News | News from Greenville, Belding and Montcalm County, Michigan
data.meta_site_name: The Daily News - Since 1854 — News from Montcalm County and Ionia County, Michigan
data.text:
‘Almost perfect’

On Thursday evening, with a weather forecast calling for rain, thunderstorms and strong winds into the weekend, Danish Festival Director Kristen Videan was preparing for the worst. Be it having to cancel events or watch from under an umbrella as people might march in a soaked Grand Dansk parade, Videan and her fellow festival organizers were ready to lower their expectations.

‘Awesome end’ to a celebration

Mari Wise didn’t quite know what to expect from the Danish Festival’s lighted drone show Saturday evening at the Greenville High School parking lot. Yet when the nearly 15-minute show ended, the Greenville woman’s words were “Awesome! It was better than fireworks! It was the coolest!”

Thousands come together to enjoy Grand Dansk Parade

Jim and Lynette Salzwenel were two of the many who lined the Grand Dansk Parade route Saturday afternoon. The Lowell couple first came to last year’s Danish Festival after being invited by friends and decided to return again this year.

After remodel, Danish Cultural Center welcomes back guests, traditional events during festival

For the Danish Cultural Center, their mission is to educate, preserve and disseminate the rich heritage and traditions of their Danish immigrants. It is a goal they have 365 days of the year, but none more so than on Danish Festival weekend.

Wet and wild competition

Being a firefighter can be a rough job. They can be called to duty at any time — during a family birthday party, in the middle of the night or just when they’ve sat down to dinner. Firefighters can see some tough things and experience tragedies when things don’t go right. On Saturday, however, those brave men and women were able to put their skills to use in a way that generated smiles and plenty of laughter in a lighthearted — and very wet — competition.

Lakeview man charged with felony for striking pedestrian in Greenville

A 60-year-old Greenville man remains in critical condition Monday after being struck by a vehicle while attempting to cross Lafayette Street in downtown Greenville Saturday evening. According to the Greenville Department of Public Safety, the Greenville man, whose name is not being released at this time, was crossing N. Lafayette Street (M-91), near Grove Street at approximately 11:18 p.m. when he was struck by a passenger vehicle.

A podcast with passion

For the past 40 years, Duane Weed has been telling stories through his multimedia talents, with his company filming numerous weddings, anniversaries, commercials, and countless other events. However, his work as a storyteller may only be just beginning.

MCC projecting largest fall enrollment increase since 2007

Upon starting his tenure as the new president of Montcalm Community College on July 1, Bradley Barrick was more than excited to personally welcome students to campus this fall. During Tuesday’s meeting of the MCC Board, held at the college’s Greenville campus, Bradley was optimistic as he provided an update on preparations leading up to the start of classes on Monday.

Greenville pedestrian in critical condition after being hit by vehicle on Lafayette StreetFree Access

A a 60-year old Greenville man remains in critical condition after being struck by a vehicle when attempting to cross Lafayette Street in downtown Greenville Saturday evening. According to the Greenville Department of Public Safety, the Greenville man, whose name is not being released at this time, was crossing N. Lafayette Street (M-91), near Grove Street, when he was struck by a passenger vehicle driven by a 70-year old Lakeview man.

‘Rain or shine’

With rain in the forecast Thursday evening, one of the first events at this year’s Danish Festival was in jeopardy of being canceled. Every year the Danish Festival Band performs an evening concert on the Thursday of the festival at Tower Riverside Park, and during that concert, dozens of Danish Dandies make their appearance, performing routines with pom poms, batons and flags for the crowd.

Despite rainy conditions, vendors old and new return to Danish Festival

For the past 29 years, the German Almond Haus has been set up on the corner of Lafayette and Cass streets, sending out the enticing smell of roasted almonds. Though it is a German house, almonds are also a resource in Denmark, used in dishes such a risalamande (rice pudding) and almond slivers sprinkled on kringle.

New features at Danish Festival’s Hans Christensen Anderson Park a hit with festivalgoers

After walking through the artisan craft booths, Stacey Watts was thankful to come to the Hans Christian Andersen Park, a half-block area of various kids activities on Friday afternoon. An area set up with puppets and a play kitchen with play food, arts and crafts, sensory bins, dress-up clothes, Fisher Price toys, cars and trucks, a bounce house, doll houses and furnishings, Pretty Ponies and more, it was the perfect place for her grandchildren.

‘A disaster on many levels’

The Belvidere Township clerk is being investigated for alleged nonfeasance and willful neglect of duty regarding actions during the Aug. 6 election. Judy Spring was appointed clerk this past March; she is the township’s fourth clerk in a just year and a half. Among multiple allegations, Spring allegedly allowed Ken Purchase, a candidate for township supervisor in that election, and Yolanda Lane, a candidate for township treasurer in that election, to access the electronic poll book (EPB) and the qualified voter file (QVF) on and/or before election day.

6 decades of celebrations

In commemorating 60 years of Danish Festivals, things came full-circle Wednesday evening when Janet Wulf-Marvin approached the crowd that had gathered at Heritage Park. Several dozen spectators circled around the park’s “Ugly Duckling” statue and fountain to welcome the start of this year’s festival during its opening ceremony. In terms of participation in that welcome, there is likely none better to provide an assist than Wulf-Marvin.

Magistrate Magirl

The new magistrate and administrator of Montcalm County District Court will be a familiar face to many. The Montcalm County Board of Commissioners on Monday voted to hire Dennis Magirl to fill a vacancy created by Brian Wagner, whose last day is today (Friday) as Wagner took a job with the State Court Administrative Office.

Building a house

This season looks to be a unique one for Taryn Muilenburg and the Central Montcalm varsity volleyball team. From having the tallest front row of players she’s had as the Hornets’ head coach to having multiple players with the ability to rotate in and out of different positions, Muilenburg and the Hornets are eager to get out on the court and show their opponents what they’re capable of.

Danish Dash: A ‘fun’ but ‘brutal’ run

At 3.1 miles, the annual Danish Dash 5K may not be considered the most daunting of races to the outside observer. However, for those who participate and make the trek up the endless hill of Marvel Drive near the final leg of the race, it might as well be a marathon.

Meeting high standards

It’s no secret that Belding football has dominated the game over the last couple of seasons, most recently winning back-to-back conference championships in the OK Silver. With their eye on a third title this season, the Black Knights look to take a deeper dive in the postseason as well.

‘The sky’s the limit’

The expectations are set remarkably high for the Central Montcalm football team this upcoming season. Expectations are set by Hornet players themselves.

‘The best is standard’

The upcoming season for the Greenville varsity football team is one to be full of new experiences, both on the field and behind the scenes. Between entering a new conference and having a brand new head coach, the Yellow Jackets are preparing for what they anticipate to be an exciting season full of new opportunities for the program. The Yellow Jackets, who finished last season 2-7, made their return to Legacy Field earlier this week, gearing up for their season opener in just a couple of weeks.

Raising the bar

Five of the last six seasons have shown great levels of success for the Tri County football team when it comes to playoff appearances. Even in August, they look to keep the momentum going and chase after another one. The Vikings, who finished last season with a 7-3 record, have been hard at work on the field this week looking to hit the ground running for their first game in just a few short weeks.

A player-led team

Last year’s football season was a tough one for the Lakeview Wildcats. From having to play their home games offsite due to field renovations to pushing through times of adversity, the Wildcats saw it all last season and were forced to dig deep and stay mentally tough. This year, the Wildcats, who went 3-6 overall last season, are back and ready to make their triumphant return to their own stomping grounds where they’ll play six games on their newly refreshed field.

Setting goals

The Ionia football team is making this upcoming season their own with a laundry list of goals they hope to achieve. The Bulldogs finished last season with a record of 5-5 after drawing a tough district pool and falling to Forest Hills Eastern in the playoff opener. This year, they have every intention of chasing not only a couple of titles but a home playoff game as well.

‘The never quit attitude’

Last year’s inaugural season for the Montcalm Community College volleyball team was about testing the waters of collegiate volleyball. This year, they’re hungry for more. The Centurions, who went 7-15 overall last season, made their grand return to the gym last Thursday to get the ball rolling for what they hope to be another great season for the program. Although it’s been just over a week of having the entire team together, head coach Kara Youngs is most excited for the energy she has on her roster this season.

Greenville graduate Emma Rewa excited for Centurion basketball

Basketball has been a huge part of Emma Rewa’s life ever since she was little. Now, she intends to take her lifelong passion for the game to the next level. The recent Greenville High School graduate established herself as a model example of what it means to be a Yellow Jacket during her two years playing at the varsity level. With the new school year only weeks away, she plans to continue her academic and athletic careers at Montcalm Community College, not too far from home.

‘Making memories’

The upcoming basketball season doesn’t start for at least another three months. That’s not stopping the Greenville girls basketball teams from getting in the gym this summer and getting a leg up when it comes to establishing a strong team connection.

The Woodstock of basketball

A total of 425 teams and 31 brackets and an endless amount of memories were created and celebrated over the weekend in Belding. The streets of downtown were lined up with pop-up three-on-three basketball courts that were full of passionate basketball players of all ages, all coming together to celebrate the 50th birthday of a summer staple to the Black Knight community: Gus Macker basketball.
